 I. INTRODUCTION The rapid increase in borrowing by developing countries in the mid-1970's led to heightened concern over their capacity to service debt. In an uncertain international environment, questions still remain regarding debt problems, the implications for the debt structure of the rise in borrowing from private sources, the maturity profile and costs of debt, and the continuing willingness and ability of private banks to supply a major portion of the financing needs of developing countries. This paper discusses what is known about the evolution of the debt of developing countries in the 1970's. It benefits from recent improvements in the availability of data, particularly with regard to loans from and debt owed by private entities. Specifically, it incorporates data of the private sector not guaranteed by public entities in the country of the borrower. These data are still estimates in part, but enormous advances have been made. More information has also become available on the geographical dis- tribution of the claims and liabilities of private banks. The author gratefully acknowledges the assistance of Linda Gard in the preparation of this paper, and the extensive cooperation received from the staff of the External Debt Division. In addition, the paper has benefitted from useful comments and suggestions received from Ram Chopra, Al Cizauskas, Francis Colaco, Helen Hughes, Tom Klein and Jo Saxe. They are of course in no way responsible for the views expressed or any remaining (or subsequently added) errors.

BORROWING AND THE GROWTH OF DEBT At the end of 1977, the total medium- and long-term debt of developing countries was $258.4 billion, of which $206.3 billion, or 80%, was owed or guaranteed by developing country governments or government agencies. In addition, these countries were conservatively estimated to have had out- standing short-term financial obligations of $50-60 billion, although this figure is subject to greater uncertainty, in part because short-term liabilities are subject to considerable seasonal and other fluctuations. Outstanding IMF credit, by convention not reflected in the above figures,was almost $8 billion. Thus, the "total" external debt liabilities of these countries were about $320 billion. In the four years from the end of 1973 through 1977, a period when the international economy was adjusting to shocks (the subject of ample dis- cussion elsewhere), developing countries' medium- and long-term debt more than doubled (in nominal terms), increasing at the equivalent of 21.5% per annum. Perhaps because of the attention paid early in that period to the then-loom- ing requirements that financial adjustments be made, it is not always recog- nized that outstanding debt had also doubled in the preceding four-year period, from the end of 1969 through 1973, going from $57.1 billion to $118.4 billion, equivalent to an average annual rate of 20.0%. Although there is no single appropriate deflator for international financial claims, it may be noted that, using the GDP deflator of OECD North countries, expressed in US dollars, the rate of growth of outstanding debt in constant dollars was considerably lower

THE CHANGING STRUCTURE OF DEBT Debt Owed to Private Creditors Debt to private creditors has increased much more rapidly than debt to official agencies. Whereas, at the end of 1973, debt held by private creditors was only 8% higher than officially-held debt, during 1974-77, pri- vate entities lent $2 for every $1 of official lending. Private creditors held 60% of the outstanding debt at the end of 1977, compared to 45% in 1969, and accounted for 64% of the increase in debt between the end of 1969 and 1977. It should be noted that the rate of growth of debt of private lenders in 1973-77, though high (26%), was about the same as in 1969-73. Among priva.te creditors, there has been a shift toward lending through financial markets and away from lending by suppliers. indeed, debt to supplIers increased more slowly than debt to official agencies: as a proportion of public debt owed to private creditors, it fell from 53% at the end of 1969 to 19% in 1977. The increased availability of loans from private banks was facili- tated by institutional developments in the international financial markets in the early 1970's. These developments permitted a growing pool of short-
 - 11 - term funds (mostly offshore) to be transformed into long-term loans without the previous risks. The syndicated floating rate bank credit transferred the risk of interest rate fluctuations from lenders to borrowers. Through the practice of syndication, a wholesale market could be developed, lowering costs, while large sums could be raised at the same time that the exposure of any one lender arising from a single trans- action could be reduced. The growth of an international interbank deposit and money market facilitated the funding of loans, particularly for banks lending in other than their home currencies. These various developments, which initially gave banks a compe- titive edge over other lenders, had the effect of preparing both borrowers and the financial markets for the much larger demands for international financing in the mid-1970's. These demands have come not only from developing countries. Despite the very rapid growth of borrowing by developing countries, their share in total loans on these markets, though large, has fallen off somewhat from 1976 to 1978 after rising sharply from 1973 to 1975, at least as measured by publicized loan commitments (see Table 5). INDICATORS OF INDEBTEDNESS As an aid in assessing the growth of debt, and to distinguish it from the growth of indebtedness, debt can be measured against other economic magnitudes, or "scaled." A great deal of effort has gone into the search for one or more indicators which singly or in combination have predictive value for debt service capacity and performance. Success has been very limited particularly for individual countries where the assessment of the risks attached to additional debt is one of the central tasks of any lender, or borrower for that matter. Here, rather than looking at individual countries the growth of debt is reviewed on the basis of groups of countries in relation to their growth of income, of exports or GNP, and to the growth of their reserves and other external assets. Such a review gives an indication of the
 - 17 - broad patterns of development and may throw some light on the relations between these groups of countries with lenders. A. The advent of the widespread use of floating interest rates on loans from financial institutions has altered some of the traditional relationships regarding real interest rate calculations. Fixed rate loans confer a real gain (or reduction in the cost of carrying debt) to the extent that there is an acceleration in unanticipated inflation--as occurred during recent years. Conversely, if inflation decelerates, the real cost of debt may rise. (This point is separate, of course, from the general question of whether developing
 - 32 - countries have gained or lost overall from inflation.) Floating rate loans tend to reduce the potential gains and losses for borrowers which can arise from shifts in Inflation, as expectations about inflation are reflected in short-term money market rates with respect to which floating rate loans are adjusted, usually every six months. At the same time, floating interest rates introduce additional uncertainty for borrowers, as the total nominal interest cost of a floating rate loan, cannot be known except ex post. (Put another way, floating rate loans introduce fluctuations in nominal interest rates, but tend to keep real interest rates more constant than with fixed rate loans.) A further consideration is that interest rates on floating rate loans are set at a margin above short term interest rates, despite the long term maturity of the loan. Market Rearrangements A steep rise of amortization payments by middle income countries to private creditors in 1976-78 coincided with improvements in the current account positions of these countries overall and very liquid conditions in financial markets. These conditions led to the easing of the terms for new loans from the markets, as discussed earlier. The result has been a considerable improvement in the liquidity position of these countries, achieved by (a) the replacement of old loans coming due with new loans at longer maturities and lower spreads; (b) borrowing of amounts in excess of current (or anticipation of future) needs and redepositing of the proceeds, reflected in higher levels of reserves and other foreign assets; and (c) to a more limited extent, renegotiation of old loans to reflect current conditions, and/or early repayment of these loans, combined with new borrowing. These activities may be seen as part of a growing sophistication of developing countries, many of which are actively managing the structure of their external assets and liabilities to take advantage of changes in market conditions. It also points to their growing importance as the users of private banking services, and the continued development of competition among banks for business relationships with developing countries.
 - 43 - V. SUMMARY AND CONCLUSION Developing countries have made use of foreign loans to finance their imports, as a supplement to domestic sources of funds for investment, and for purposes of overall balance of payments and economic management. Net borrowing by these countries has increased rapidly, from a total of $9.3 billion in 1970 to an average of $36.6 billion in 1975-77, an annual average rate of growth of almost 26% in current US dollars, Borrowing rose in relation to the imports of these countries, from the equivalent of 9.6% of their imports in 1970 to 11.1% in 1975-77. This expansion of borrowing was reflected in an increase of out- standing debt which averaged 21% per year, going from $57.1 billion at the end of 1969 to $258.5 billion at the end of 1977. Despite the shocks in the international economy after 1973, the rate of growth of outstanding debt did not increase appreciably in the four years from the end of 1973 to the end of 1977 as compared with the previous four-year period. Indeed, in constant US dollars, the rate of growth of debt slowed down. Private lenders have become increasingly important as sources of finance, and accounted for 64% of the rise in debt from the end of 1969 to the end of 1977; the share of total debt outstanding of developing countries owed to private creditors increased from 45% to 60% during this period. The most rapid increase has been in public and publicly-guaranteed borrowing from private banks; this debt has increased at an annual rate of over 40% during this period. The greater reliance by developing countries on loans from banks relative to other sources of finance has paralleled the expansion of international financial markets,
 - 44 - and in particular the development of the syndicated Eurocurrency credit market, where developing countries have accounted for over 50% of the publicized loans arranged since 1975. Viewing the rise of debt against other economic changes, the ratio of outstanding debt to GNP in developing countries rose from just under 16% in 1970 to just under 21% in 1977. In relation to exports, however, debt de- clined from over 87% in 1970 to just under 83% in 1977. The difference in the performance of these two ratios reflected the rapid increase in exports and their growing contribution to GNP during this period. However, if the major oil exporting countries, which experienced a sharp increase in export earnings after 1973, are excluded, the ratio of debt to exports in other developing countries rose somewhat, from 91% in 1973 to 102% in 1977. External debt may also be assessed in relation to the growth of reserves and other external assets, especially as many borrowers have used the proceeds of loans to build up these assets. At the end of 1977, official reserves (a liquid asset) were equal to 40% of outstanding debt; private banks' outstanding liabilities to developing countries were equal to 85% of their claims on these countries, 64% if oil exporting countries are excluded, at the end of 1978. There is a complementary pattern in the sources of finance used by countries at different levels of per capita income. About 94% of debt owed to private sources at the end of 1977 was by middle-income countries, accounting for 67% of the total debt of these countries. By contrast, 71% of the debt of low income countries was from official sources on concessional terms.
 - 45 - Loans from private sources are both more costly, as measured by their interest rate, and at shorter maturities than loans from official sources. Amor- tization payments on debt owed to private sources have been equal to about 16- 20% of the debt outstanding to these sources in any year, while for debt owed to official sources, this ratio has been 5-6%. About 70% of the debt outstanding to private sources at the end of 1977 was scheduled to be repaid in five years, com- pared to 24% for official-source debt. The greater reliance on private sources of finance by middle-income countries compared with low-income countries is both a reflection of and a con- tribution to the very different sets of external debt and balance of payments management issues that these two groups of countries face. For middle-income countries, the higher rollover ratio of outstanding debt, and the need for con- tinual access to private financial markets, places a premium on the maintenance of sound economic policies and financial management, and the perceptions thereof among lenders. The greater availability of private finance in recent years has given these countries greater scope for external financial management, as it has increased the vulnerability of these countries to uncertainties in the inter- national environment. Private lenders, too, have had to pay increasing attention to the assessment and management of risk in their international portfolios. Consequently, mutual incentives have been created for sound policy and an open international system. For low income countries, the level and pattern of future debt service precludes the taking on of significant new amounts of debt on other than concessional terms, in the context of their overall development
 - 46 - programs. It has been recognized that, particularly for the least developed countries, debt relief is appropriate, in the form of cancellation or other retractive adjustment of the terms of debt, at least in particular cases. The debt problems of these countries may be seen as a part of the overall scarcity of resources available to them for development.

doc.abstracts: This paper reviews the growth and changing structure of the external debt of developing countries, including their private, non-guaranteed debt, during the period 1970 through 1977. It discusses these developments in relation to other economic changes during this period, as well as the growth of external assets. Trends in debt service and the cost of debt are reviewed, along with a prospective look at patterns of debt amortization.
